text: The voltage-gated K+ channel inactivation state is responsible for the absolute refractory period.
explanation: The voltage-gated Na+ inactivation state is responsible for the absolute refractory period. K+ voltage-gated channel does not go through any inactivation state.

text: The voltage-gated Na+ channel is responsible for the depolarization phase of the action potential.
When temporal summation occurs, spatial summation cannot.
explanation: Temporal and spatial summation can occur simultaneously.

text: The firing rate influences the amplitude of the resulting action potential in the post-synaptic cell.
explanation: It can affect the temporal summation and therefore the amplitude of the post-synaptic potentials, not of the action potential.

text: The frontal lobe houses the primary motor function.
In the brain primary somatosensory cortex (Penfield homunculus) the extension of the cortical region which maps a specific body region is proportional to that body region's volume.
explanation: The extension of the cortical region which maps a specific body region is proportional to the number of receptors, not to the body region's volume.

text: The short-term synaptic plasticity involves a structural change in the post-synaptic membrane.
explanation: It involves only functional changes.

text: The brain operates at the temporal scale of milliseconds.
The neurons' spatial orientation affects the amplitude of EEG signals
The synchronicity of the neural activity affects the amplitude of EEG signals.
Scalp EEG is mainly produced by deep (subcortical) regions.
explanation: It is mainly produced by cortical regions.

text: The electrical variation of the membrane potential that mainly contributes to EEG is the action potential.
explanation: The synchronous variations of post-synaptic potentials (and their extracellular counterpart) are the main contributors to EEG signals.

text: A neuron's firing rate tuning curve for movement direction shows (panel A) the spike trains obtained - for different trials - from a neuron of the primary motor cortex in correspondence to an arm movement, and (panel B) the firing rate f of the same neuron as a function of the angle s of the same movement direction. When the firing rate is 55 Hz, I can infer which movement direction produced that response.
explanation: Yes, because there's a unique value of s that can produce a neuronal response with that firing rate.

text: In reference to the neuron's firing rate tuning curve for movement direction: from the curve I can conclude that this neuron is tuned to be more active in correspondence to a specific movement direction.
In reference to the neuron's firing rate tuning curve for movement direction: the firing rate f in panel B was computed as the average of the neural response function across trials.
If Cxy(f) is the Ordinary Coherence between x and y, Cxy(f)=Cyx(f).
Given the Granger Index Gxy between two time series x and y, a negative value of Gxy means an inverse precedence between the two time series.
explanation: A negative value of Gxy means that the residual of the bivariate model is higher than in the simple model, which is probably due to an incorrect modeling.

text: In the event of data paucity, the Partial Directed Coherence (PDC) is the most accurate estimator of causality in the statistical sense.
explanation: When we have a limited amount of data, PDC returns inaccurate results due to the low ratio between data samples and model parameters.

text: In a directed graph, all indices are doubled with respect to a corresponding undirected one (i.e., the graph where all the directions have been removed).
explanation: There is no such correspondence between the indices of a directed graph and those of its corresponding undirected one.

text: Random networks have a smaller Local Efficiency than regular (lattice) networks.
In a graph, the minimum Divisibility is equal to zero.
explanation: According to the most used normalization, the minimum Divisibility is equal to 0.5. More generally, even with different choices of the term k, D can never be equal to zero.

text: Divisibility and Modularity are measures of segregation of a network.
Regular networks have a smaller Global Efficiency than random networks.
Modularity values belong to the interval [0,1]
explanation: Modularity can take positive or negative values.

text: An IPSP consists of a depolarization of the post-synaptic cell membrane.
explanation: Being inhibitory, it consists of a hyperpolarization of the membrane.

text: The inactivation of the voltage-gated Na+ channel is responsible for the absolute refractory period.
The most informative parameter of the spike train in output to a neuronal cell is the amplitude of the spikes.
explanation: The amplitude of all the spikes is the same, so this is not an informative parameter.

text: The firing rate of the pre-synaptic neuron influences the temporal summation of the PSPs in the post-synaptic cell.
The frontal lobe houses the primary visual function.
explanation: The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe.

text: In the primary motor cortex (Penfield homunculus) the extension of the cortical region which controls a specific body region is proportional to that body region's volume.
explanation: The extension of the cortical region which controls a specific body region is proportional to the number of motor nerves, not to the body region's volume.

text: To record in vivo measures of the membrane potential over the axon of a single neural cell, you will use extracellular measures.
The EEG signal is mainly generated by action potentials.
explanation: It is mainly generated by post-synaptic potentials.

text: A neuron's firing rate tuning curve for retinal disparity shows (panel B) the firing rate f of a neuron in the primary visual cortex as a function of the retinal disparity angle s (panel A). From the figure, we can infer that the neuron responds mainly to positive s (far-tuned neuron).
In reference to the neuron's firing rate tuning curve for retinal disparity: from the curve, if the retinal disparity is equal to -0.5, I can infer which firing rate will be produced by the neuron
explanation: It will be equal to 0

text: In reference to the neuron's firing rate tuning curve for retinal disparity: from the curve, if the neuron firing rate is equal to 0 Hz I can exactly infer which retinal disparity produced that response
explanation: The retinal disparity in degrees cannot be inferred when the firing rate is equal to 0, because a large range of negative values would produce the same response.

text: To record in vitro measures of the membrane potential over the dendrites of a neural cell, you will use extracellular measures
explanation: Extracellular measures are able to capture only the sequence of APs, not he E/IPSPs that occur over the dendrites. To this purpose, we will use intracellular recordings.

text: The part of the pyramidal neuron that acts as a current dipole is the axon
explanation: It's the dendritic tree.

text: A neuron's firing rate distribution for visual motion direction shows the firing rate distribution, obtained for a neuron of the primary visual cortex in response to the motion direction of dots on the screen in two possible directions (+ and -) and with different levels of coherence between the dots. Discriminability d' when the coherence=3.2% is higher than when it's =12.8%.
explanation: The discriminability d' is higher for higher values of the coherence level.

text: In reference to the neuron's firing rate distribution for visual motion direction: among the two distributions (r, or r-), r, is the one affected by the coherence level
The normalized Partial Directed Coherence E[0, 1]
The Granger Test is more suitable than the Ordinary Coherence to obtain a spectral measure
explanation: The Granger Test is not a spectral measure.

text: If Cxy(f) is the ordinary coherence between x and y, Cxy(f)=Cyx(f)
The difference between the Wiener's and Granger's definitions of causality in the statistical sense is that Granger indicated a modeling framework to be used to test causality
Regular networks have a smaller Global Efficiency than random networks
Regular networks have a smaller Local Efficiency than random networks
explanation: They have a larger Local Efficiency.

text: Undirected graphs produce symmetrical adjacency matrices
Given the Granger Index Gxy between two time series x and y, a negative value of Gx->y means an inverse precedence between the two time series.
explanation: A negative value of Gxy means that the residual of the bivariate model is higher than in the simple model, which is probably due to an incorrect modeling.

text: Using Partial Directed Coherence completely solves the problem of the hidden (common) source
explanation: It can mitigate the problem, but if a source is not accessible (e.g. because of limitations of the acquisition method) even PDC cannot remove the resulting spurious connections.

text: In the Nernst equation for the electrochemical equilibrium there is a term referred to diffusional forces and a term referred to electrical forces.
Given that at a certain temperature T the Cl- equilibrium potential is equal to -80 mV, and the membrane potential is equal to -70 mV, the Cl- net current will be a depolarizing one.
explanation: If the ion equilibrium potential is more negative than the membrane potential, the ion net current will be a hyperpolarizing one.

text: The temporal summation of PSPs does not depend on the temporal distance between subsequent action potentials in the presynaptic cell.
explanation: The temporal summation occurs when the presynaptic neuron fires multiple times in close succession.

text: A hyperpolarization with respect to the resting membrane potential can cause the generation of an action potential.
explanation: The generation of an action potential is caused by a depolarization of the neuronal membrane.

text: The motor homunculus is located in the frontal lobe.
The short-term synaptic plasticity can involve a structural change in the post-synaptic membrane.
explanation: Structural changes in the post-synaptic membrane occur with long-term plasticity.

text: To measure the membrane potential over the soma of a neural cell in vitro, the correct procedure is to record extracellular measures.
explanation: To measure the membrane potential we need intracellular recordings, that can be more easily performed in vitro and on large portions of the cell, like the soma.

text: In a cortical pyramidal neuron, thalamo-cortical synapses are located in the apical portion of its dendritic tree.
explanation: They are located in the basal part of the dendritic tree.

text: Radially symmetric neurons produce a closed field and therefore do not significantly contribute to scalp EEG.
The voltage-gated K+ channel inactivation state is responsible for the absolute refractory period.
explanation: The voltage-gated Na+ inactivation state is responsible for the absolute refractory period. K+ voltage-gated channel does not go through any inactivation state.

text: The firing rate influences the amplitude of the resulting action potential in the post-synaptic cell.
explanation: It can affect the temporal summation and therefore the amplitude of the post-synaptic potentials, not of the action potential.

text: Temporal and spatial summation can occur simultaneously.
The brain operates at the temporal scale of milliseconds.
The frontal lobe houses the primary visual function.
explanation: The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe.

text: The synchronicity of the neural activity affects the amplitude of EEG signals.
The neurons' spatial orientation affects the amplitude of EEG signals
The short-term synaptic plasticity involves a structural change in the post-synaptic membrane.
explanation: The short-term synaptic plasticity only involves functional changes (not structural ones)

text: Scalp EEG is mainly produced by deep (subcortical) regions.
explanation: It is mainly produced by cortical regions.

text: The part of the pyramidal neuron that acts as a current dipole is the axon
explanation: It's the dendritic tree.

text: An IPSP consists of a depolarization of the post-synaptic cell membrane.
explanation: Being inhibitory, it consists of a hyperpolarization of the membrane.

text: The voltage-gated Na+ channel is responsible for the absolute refractory period.
The most informative parameter of the spike train in output to a neuronal cell is the amplitude of the spikes.
explanation: The amplitude of all the spikes is the same, so this is not an informative parameter.

text: The firing rate of the pre-synaptic neuron influences the temporal summation of the PSPs in the post-synaptic cell.
The frontal lobe houses the primary visual function.
explanation: The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe.

text: In the brain primary motor cortex (Penfield homunculus) the extension of the cortical region which controls a specific body region is proportional to that body region's volume.
explanation: The extension of the cortical region which controls a specific body region is proportional to the number of motor nerves, not to the body region's volume.

text: The short-term synaptic plasticity involves an irreversible change in the post-synaptic membrane.
explanation: The short-term changes are temporary.

text: To record in vivo measures of the membrane potential over the axon of a single neural cell, you will use extracellular measures.
The EEG signal is mainly generated by action potentials.
explanation: It is mainly generated by post-synaptic potentials.

text: The voltage-gated K+ channel inactivation state is responsible for the absolute refractory period.
explanation: The voltage-gated Na+ inactivation state is responsible for the absolute refractory period. K+ voltage-gated channel does not go through any inactivation state.

text: The voltage-gated Na+ channel is responsible for the repolarization phase of the action potential.
explanation: The repolarization phase of the action potential is due to the opening of the voltage-gated K+ channel.

text: Temporal and spatial summation can occur simultaneously.
The firing rate influences the amplitude of the resulting action potential in the post-synaptic cell.
explanation: It can affect the temporal summation and therefore the amplitude of the post-synaptic potentials, not of the action potential.

text: The frontal lobe houses the primary visual function.
explanation: The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe.

text: In the brain primary motor cortex (Penfield homunculus) the extension of the cortical region which controls a specific body region is proportional to that body region's volume.
explanation: The extension of the cortical region which controls a specific body region is proportional to the number of motor nerves, not to the body region's volume.

text: Ion pumps are based on a passive membrane transportation mechanism.
explanation: They require an energy expenditure by the cell, therefore they are based on an active mechanism.

text: Given that at a certain temperature T the Cl- equilibrium potential is equal to -80 mV, and the membrane potential is equal to -70 mV, the Cl- net current will be directed from the inside of the cell toward the outside.
explanation: If the ion equilibrium potential is more negative than the membrane potential, the ion net current will be a hyperpolarizing one. Since Cl- is a negative ion family, its net hyperpolarizing current will be directed from the outside of the cell toward the inside.

text: In chemical synapses, when a neurotransmitter opens the K+ gated channels, the resulting PSP is an inhibitory one.
explanation: K+ gated channels allow the flow of a hyperpolarizing ion current, which in turn produces an inhibitory PSP.

text: The continuous conduction is faster than the saltatory (myelinated) one
explanation: The myelinated conduction is faster than the continuous one.

text: Two ipsilateral regions belong to the same hemisphere.
The unmasking of latent synaptic connections is part of the mechanisms behind brain plasticity.
To detect a sequence of action potentials over the axon of a neural cell in vivo, the correct procedure is to record extracellular measures.
The cortical pyramidal neurons are oriented tangentially to the cortical surface.
explanation: They are oriented normally to the cortical surface.

text: Synchronously activated neurons produce a larger EEG signal than the same amount of neurons when they are asynchronous.
In the Nernst equation for the electrochemical equilibrium there is a term referred to diffusional forces and a term referred to electrical forces.
Given that at a certain temperature T the Cl- equilibrium potential is equal to -80 mV, and the membrane potential is equal to -70 mV, the Cl- net current will be a depolarizing one.
explanation: If the ion equilibrium potential is more negative than the membrane potential, the ion net current will be a hyperpolarizing one.

text: The temporal summation of PSPs does not depend on the temporal distance between subsequent action potentials in the presynaptic cell.
explanation: The temporal summation occurs when the presynaptic neuron fires multiple times in close succession.

text: A hyperpolarization with respect to the resting membrane potential can cause the generation of an action potential.
explanation: The generation of an action potential is caused by a depolarization of the neuronal membrane.

text: The motor homunculus is located in the frontal lobe.
The short-term synaptic plasticity can involve a structural change in the post-synaptic membrane.
explanation: Structural changes in the post-synaptic membrane occur with long-term plasticity.

text: To measure the membrane potential over the soma of a neural cell in vitro, the correct procedure is to record extracellular measures.
explanation: To measure the membrane potential we need intracellular recordings, that can be more easily performed in vitro and on large portions of the cell, like the soma.

text: In a cortical pyramidal neuron, thalamo-cortical synapses are located in the apical portion of its dendritic tree.
explanation: They are located in the basal part of the dendritic tree.
